quote: فقال جاندالف: إنني معكم في الوقت الحاضر، ولكن قريبا لن أكون معكم. إنني لست ذاهبا إلى المقاطعة. ينبغي عليكم أن تسووا أموركم بأنفسكم، هذا ما تم تدريبكم من أجله. ألم تفهموا بعد؟ لقد انتهى وقتي وزماني. لم تعد بعد مهمتي أن أصحح الأشياء وأقومها، ولا أن أساعد الأشخاص في أن يفعلوا ذلك. وبالنسبة لكم أنتم يا أصدقائي الأعزاء، فلن تحتاجوا إلى أي مساعدة. لقد كبرتم الآن. كبرتم حقا وصرتم طوالا جدا. إنكم بين العظماء، ولم يعد يساورني أي خوف على الإطلاق على أي واحد منكم. ولكن إذا كنتم ستعرفون، فإنني سوف أحيد عن الطريق سريعا. سوف أتبادل حديثا طويلا مع بومباديل. حديث لم يحدث قط أن تبادت مثله طوال حياتي. إنه جامع طحالب، وقد كنت أنا صخرا كتب عليه أن يتدحرج ويدور. ولكن أيام تدحرجي ودوراني تصل إلى نهايتها، والآن سوف يكون لدينا الكثير ليقوله كل منا للآخر.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: فقال جاندالف: إنني معكم في الوقت الحاضر، ولكن قريبا لن أكون معكم. إنني لست ذاهبا إلى المقاطعة. ينبغي عليكم أن تسووا أموركم بأنفسكم، هذا ما تم تدريبكم من أجله. ألم تفهموا بعد؟ لقد انتهى وقتي وزماني. لم تعد بعد مهمتي أن أصحح الأشياء وأقومها، ولا أن أساعد الأشخاص في أن يفعلوا ذلك. وبالنسبة لكم أنتم يا أصدقائي الأعزاء، فلن تحتاجوا إلى أي مساعدة. لقد كبرتم الآن. كبرتم حقا وصرتم طوالا جدا. إنكم بين العظماء، ولم يعد يساورني أي خوف على الإطلاق على أي واحد منكم. ولكن إذا كنتم ستعرفون، فإنني سوف أحيد عن الطريق سريعا. سوف أتبادل حديثا طويلا مع بومباديل. حديث لم يحدث قط أن تبادت مثله طوال حياتي. إنه جامع طحالب، وقد كنت أنا صخرا كتب عليه أن يتدحرج ويدور. ولكن أيام تدحرجي ودوراني تصل إلى نهايتها، والآن سوف يكون لدينا الكثير ليقوله كل منا للآخر.
summary: Gandalf tells his companions that he is leaving them soon and will not be returning to the Shire. He explains that his time for directly fixing things and helping others is over, and they must now handle their own affairs, as they are trained and ready. He assures them that they have matured into great individuals who no longer need his assistance, and he has no fear for their future. He then reveals he will have a long, unprecedented conversation with Bombadil, signaling a deep personal change for him, moving from a life of constant action (a "rolling stone") to a more reflective existence.

quote:
Alive without breath;
as cold as death;
never thirsting, ever drinking;
clad in mail, never clinking.
Drowns on dry land,
thinks an island
is a mountain;
thinks a fountain
is a puff of air.
So sleek, so fair!
What a joy to meet!
We only wish
to catch a fish,
so juicy-sweet!
prompt_template:
Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Alive without breath;
as cold as death;
never thirsting, ever drinking;
clad in mail, never clinking.
Drowns on dry land,
thinks an island
is a mountain;
thinks a fountain
is a puff of air.
So sleek, so fair!
What a joy to meet!
We only wish
to catch a fish,
so juicy-sweet!
summary: This riddle describes a fish. It lives underwater, so it doesn't need to breathe air and is always surrounded by water. It has a smooth, scaly body and moves silently. A fish cannot survive on dry land. The poem also suggests that a fish has a unique way of seeing the world, perceiving land as large obstacles and water sprays as mere puffs of air. Ultimately, the speaker expresses a desire to catch this sleek, sweet creature for food.

quote: The world is grey, the mountains old, The forge’s fire is ashen-cold; No harp is wrung, no hammer falls: The darkness dwells in Durin’s halls; The shadow lies upon his tomb In Moria, in Khazad-dûm.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: The world is grey, the mountains old, The forge’s fire is ashen-cold; No harp is wrung, no hammer falls: The darkness dwells in Durin’s halls; The shadow lies upon his tomb In Moria, in Khazad-dûm.
summary: This quote paints a bleak picture of a world that has lost its vibrancy and warmth. It specifically laments the desolate state of the once-mighty Dwarven kingdom of Durin, known as Moria or Khazad-dûm. What was once a bustling place of fire, music, and industrious work is now cold, silent, and utterly abandoned. Only darkness and the shadow of death remain, marking it as a ruin where a great legacy has fallen.

quote: he found himself wondering, since Entish was such an ‘unhasty’ language, whether they had yet got further than Good Morning;
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: he found himself wondering, since Entish was such an ‘unhasty’ language, whether they had yet got further than Good Morning;
summary: The speaker wondered about the incredibly slow nature of Entish, the language spoken by the Ents. Given its 'unhasty' and deliberate pace, he humorously questioned whether they could have possibly progressed beyond just saying 'Good Morning' to one another, implying that any conversation among them would take an extraordinarily long time.

quote:
-Desleal es aquel que se despide cuando el camino se oscurece.
-Quizá, pero no jure que caminará en las tinieblas quien no ha visto la caída de la noche.
prompt_template:
Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: -Desleal es aquel que se despide cuando el camino se oscurece.
-Quizá, pero no jure que caminará en las tinieblas quien no ha visto la caída de la noche.
summary: This quote explores the nature of loyalty during difficult times. The first statement suggests that someone who leaves when circumstances become challenging is disloyal. However, the second part offers a more cautious perspective, implying that while this might be true, one shouldn't promise to endure hardship if they haven't truly experienced real adversity yet. It's easy to talk about staying strong, but the true test only comes when facing actual darkness.

quote: In place of the Dark Lord you will set up a Queen. And I shall not be dark, but beautiful and terrible as the Morning and the Night! Fair as the Sea and the Sun and the Snow upon the Mountain! summary: This quote describes a powerful new Queen who will replace an existing "Dark Lord." She claims she won't be evil in the same way, but will be both beautiful and terrifying, embodying the majesty of nature like the sun and sea, yet also the destructive force of a storm. She sees herself as incredibly strong, more powerful than anything on Earth. Her reign will be so absolute and overwhelming that everyone will be forced to admire and adore her, while simultaneously feeling a sense of hopelessness and despair at her unstoppable might.

quote: We are plain quiet folk and have no use for adventures. Nasty disturbing uncomfortable things! Make you late for dinner!
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: We are plain quiet folk and have no use for adventures. Nasty disturbing uncomfortable things! Make you late for dinner!
summary: This quote describes a group of ordinary, peaceful people who strongly dislike adventures. They see exciting experiences as unpleasant, disruptive, and uncomfortable. Their biggest concern is that such events might even make them late for dinner, highlighting their preference for a simple, routine-filled life over any kind of excitement or disturbance.

quote: It was in fairy-stories that I first divined the potency of the words, and the wonder of the things, such as stone, and wood, and iron; tree and grass; house and fire; bread and wine.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: It was in fairy-stories that I first divined the potency of the words, and the wonder of the things, such as stone, and wood, and iron; tree and grass; house and fire; bread and wine.

quote: Even in ancient days they were, as a rule, shy of 'the Big Folk', as they call us, and now they avoid us with dismay and are becoming hard to find.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Even in ancient days they were, as a rule, shy of 'the Big Folk', as they call us, and now they avoid us with dismay and are becoming hard to find.

This shyness has worsened over time; now, they actively stay away from us with a sense of distress or unhappiness. As a result, they are becoming increasingly rare and difficult to encounter.

quote: Far off there was a great hill of shadow, and out of that shadow, which was its root, he saw the King's Tree springing up, tower upon tower, into the sky, and its light was like the sun at noon; and it bore at once leaves and flowers and fruits uncounted, and not one was the same as any other that grew on The Tree.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Far off there was a great hill of shadow, and out of that shadow, which was its root, he saw the King's Tree springing up, tower upon tower, into the sky, and its light was like the sun at noon; and it bore at once leaves and flowers and fruits uncounted, and not one was the same as any other that grew on The Tree.
summary: The quote describes a magnificent and powerful tree, known as the King's Tree. It is seen growing out of a vast, dark hill, which acts as its base. What makes it truly remarkable is that it produces countless leaves, flowers, and fruits all at once, and every single one of these items is unique and different from the others growing on the tree.

quote: But I should have said that the story had for the more intelligent reader a great number of philosophical and mythical implications that enormously enhanced without detracting from the surface 'adventure'. I found the blend of vera historia with mythos irresistible.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: But I should have said that the story had for the more intelligent reader a great number of philosophical and mythical implications that enormously enhanced without detracting from the surface 'adventure'. quote: I’ve more need of thoughts than of sleep.

They are prioritizing mental activity and the pursuit of ideas over the basic human need for sleep, indicating that their thoughts are currently more vital or compelling to them than a break.

quote: In pigri giardini, molti fiori come te gli dèi innamorati sono soliti baciare d'un bacio che assomiglia al miele; e poi li buttano via, sciupati, e li calpestano, mentre emanano il profumo loro. summary: This quote suggests that beautiful people, like flowers in a relaxed garden, are passionately admired and enjoyed by those who indulge, much like gods sharing a sweet, honey-like kiss. The passage then asks who wouldn't be tempted to experience such fleeting delights—tasting sweetness or crushing delicate beauty—if it helps pass the time, just as the gods do.

quote:
Good morning!" he said at last. "We don't want any adventures here, thank you! You might try over The Hill or across The Water." By this he meant that the conversation was at an end.

"What a lot of things you do use Good morning for!" said Gandalf. "Now you mean that you want to get rid of me, and that it won't be good till I move off.
prompt_template:
Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Good morning!" he said at last. "We don't want any adventures here, thank you! You might try over The Hill or across The Water." By this he meant that the conversation was at an end.

"What a lot of things you do use Good morning for!" said Gandalf. "Now you mean that you want to get rid of me, and that it won't be good till I move off.
summary: In this exchange, a character uses "Good morning!" as a polite but firm way to end a conversation and express that he wants no adventures or trouble, essentially telling the other person to leave and try somewhere else. Gandalf, however, sees through this polite dismissal. He points out the irony of using a cheerful greeting to mean the exact opposite – that the speaker actually wants him to leave, and things won't be good until he does.

quote: There is a lot more in him than you guess, and a deal more than he has any idea of himself.

quote: One has indeed personally to come under the shadow of war to feel fully its oppression; but as the years go by it seems now often forgotten that to be caught in youth by 1914 was no less hideous an experience than to be involved in 1939 and the following years. quote: We must walk open-eyed into that trap, with courage, but small hope for ourselves. For, my lords, it may well prove that we ourselves shall perish utterly in a black battle far from the living lands; so that even if Barad-dûr be thrown down, we shall not live to see a new age. But this, I deem, is our duty. And better so than to perish nonetheless - as we surely shall, if we sit here - and know as we die that no new age shall begin.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: We must walk open-eyed into that trap, with courage, but small hope for ourselves. summary: The speaker believes they must bravely face a dangerous situation, fully aware they likely won't survive. They expect to die in a terrible battle, far from home, and even if they succeed in defeating the enemy, they won't live to see the peaceful future that follows. However, they believe this sacrifice is their duty. It's better to fight and die, giving a new age a chance to begin, than to do nothing, die anyway, and guarantee that no better future will ever come.

quote: Understand one another? I fear I am beyond your comprehension. But you, Saruman, I understand now too well. I keep a clearer memory of your arguments, and deeds, than you suppose. When last I visited you, you were the jailor of Mordor, and there I was to be sent. Nay, the guest who has escaped from the roof, will think twice before he comes back in by the door.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Understand one another? I fear I am beyond your comprehension. But you, Saruman, I understand now too well. summary: The speaker tells Saruman that while Saruman may not understand them, the speaker now understands Saruman's true nature very well. Therefore, having narrowly escaped such peril before, the speaker makes it clear they will not willingly return to a dangerous situation or trust Saruman again.

quote: Non tocca a noi dominare tutte le maree del mondo; il nostro compito è di fare il possibile per la salvezza degli anni nei quali viviamo, sradicando il male dai campi che conosciamo, al fine di lasciare a coloro che verranno dopo terra sana e pulita da coltivare.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: Non tocca a noi dominare tutte le maree del mondo; il nostro compito è di fare il possibile per la salvezza degli anni nei quali viviamo, sradicando il male dai campi che conosciamo, al fine di lasciare a coloro che verranno dopo terra sana e pulita da coltivare.
summary: This quote suggests that we shouldn't try to control every single thing in the world. Instead, our true responsibility is to focus on doing what we can in our own time and within our immediate surroundings. This means actively working to remove the 'evil' or problems from the areas we understand and have influence over. The ultimate goal is to leave a healthy, clean, and fertile world for future generations to inherit and make their own.

quote: It's like in the great stories, Mr. Frodo. The ones that really mattered, full of darkness and danger they were, and sometimes you didn't want to know the end, because how could the end be happy? How could the world go back to the way it was, before so much bad had happened? But in the end, it's only a passing thing, this shadow. Even darkness must pass. A new day will come, and when the sun shines, it will shine all the clearer. Those were the stories that stayed with you, that meant something, even if you were too small to understand why. But I think I do understand. I know now. Folk in those stories had lots of chances to turn back, only they didn't. They kept going, because they were holding onto something...There's some good in this world. And it's worth fighting for.
prompt_template: Summarize the following quote in simple English in a paragraph: It's like in the great stories, Mr. Frodo. The ones that really mattered, full of darkness and danger they were, and sometimes you didn't want to know the end, because how could the end be happy? How could the world go back to the way it was, before so much bad had happened? But in the end, it's only a passing thing, this shadow. Even darkness must pass. A new day will come, and when the sun shines, it will shine all the clearer. Those were the stories that stayed with you, that meant something, even if you were too small to understand why. But I think I do understand. I know now. Folk in those stories had lots of chances to turn back, only they didn't. They kept going, because they were holding onto something...There's some good in this world. And it's worth fighting for.
summary: This quote explains that the most important stories are often those filled with immense darkness and danger, making it hard to imagine a happy outcome or a return to normal. However, it emphasizes that even the deepest despair is temporary, like a passing shadow, and a new, brighter day will always follow. The speaker realizes that the heroes in these enduring stories didn't give up, even when they had chances to turn back. They kept going because they believed in something good in the world, understanding that this good is worth fighting for, no matter how challenging the circumstances.

quote: There is some good in this world, and it's worth fighting for.

Gandalf: White shores, and beyond, a far green country under a swift sunrise.

Pippin:: Well, that isn't so bad.

Gandalf: No. No, it isn't.
summary: Pippin is worried about an impending end, but Gandalf reassures him that death isn't the final stop, but merely another step on a journey. Gandalf describes death not as a true ending, but a transition where the world's "grey rain-curtain" rolls back to reveal something beautiful and bright. He paints a picture of "white shores" and a "far green country" under a "swift sunrise," suggesting a peaceful and hopeful afterlife. Pippin, initially fearful, finds comfort in this description, realizing that such an end isn't bad at all.

quote: Recovery (which includes return and renewal of health) is a re-gaining - regaining of a clear view. I do not say ‘seeing things as they are’ and involve myself with the philosophers, though I might venture to say ‘seeing things as we are (or were) meant to see them’ - as things apart from ourselves. We need, in any case, to clean our windows; so that the things seen clearly may be freed from the drab blur of triteness or familiarity - from possessiveness. Of all faces those of our familiares are the ones both most difficult to play fantastic tricks with, and most difficult really to see with fresh attention, perceiving their likeness and unlikeness: that they are faces, and yet unique faces. This triteness is really the penalty of ‘appropriation’: the things that are trite, or (in a bad sense) familiar, are the things that we have appropriated, legally or mentally. We say we know them. They have become like the things which once attracted us by their glitter, or their colour, or their shape, and we laid hands on them, and then locked them in our hoard, acquired them, and acquiring ceased to look at them.

summary: Recovery isn't just about getting healthy; it's about regaining a clear perspective on things. This isn't about seeing objective truth, but rather about seeing things freshly, as if for the first time, without our usual assumptions or sense of ownership. We need to "clean our mental windows" to remove the dullness that comes from familiarity and possessiveness. When we feel we "know" or have "appropriated" something—whether it's a person, an idea, or an object—it often becomes trite. Like a shiny treasure we once coveted, we acquire it, lock it away, and then stop truly looking at or appreciating it.

quote:
Frodo peering forward saw in the distance two great rocks approaching: like great pinnacles or pillars of stone they seemed. Tall and sheer and ominous they stood upon either side of the stream. A narrow gap appeared between them, and the River swept the boats towards it.
‘Behold the Argonath, the Pillars of the Kings!’ cried Aragorn. ‘We shall pass them soon. Keep the boats in line, and as far apart as you can! Hold the middle of the stream!’
As Frodo was borne towards them the great pillars rose like towers to meet him. Giants they seemed to him, vast grey figures silent but threatening. Then he saw that they were indeed shaped and fashioned: the craft and power of old had wrought upon them, and still they preserved through the suns and rains of forgotten years the mighty likenesses in which they had been hewn. Upon great pedestals founded in the deep waters stood two great kings of stone: still with blurred eyes and crannied brows they frowned upon the North. The left hand of each was raised palm outwards in gesture of warning; in each right hand there was an axe; upon each head there was a crumbling helm and crown. Great power and majesty they still wore, the silent wardens of a long-vanished kingdom. Awe and fear fell upon Frodo, and he cowered down, shutting his eyes and not daring to look up as the boat drew near. Even Boromir bowed his head as the boats whirled by, frail and fleeting as little leaves, under the enduring shadow of the sentinels of Númenor. So they passed into the dark chasm of the Gates.
